title: The Brave Tin Soldier
sentence: The Brave Tin Soldier by Hans Christian Andersen THERE were once five and twenty tin soldiers  who were all brothers  for they had been made out of the same old tin spoon  ~newline~ The soldiers were all exactly alike  excepting one  who had only one leg  he had been left to the last  and then there was not enough of the melted tin to finish him  so they made him to stand firmly on one leg  and this caused him to be very remarkable  ~newline~ The table on which the tin soldiers stood  was covered with other playthings  but the most attractive to the eye was a pretty little paper castle  ~newline~ All this was very pretty  but the prettiest of all was a tiny little lady  who stood at the open door of the castle  she  also  was made of paper  and she wore a dress of clear muslin  with a narrow blue ribbon over her shoulders just like a scarf  ~newline~ In front of these was fixed a glittering tinsel rose  as large as her whole face  ~newline~ The little lady was a dancer  and she stretched out both her arms  and raised one of her legs so high  that the tin soldier could not see it at all  and he thought that she  like himself  had only one leg  ~newline~ Then he laid himself at full length on the table behind a snuff box that stood upon it  so that he could peep at the little delicate lady  who continued to stand on one leg without losing her balance  ~newline~ When evening came  the other tin soldiers were all placed in the box  and the people of the house went to bed  ~newline~ The tin soldiers rattled in their box  they wanted to get out and join the amusements  but they could not open the lid  ~newline~ Only the tin soldier and the dancer remained in their places  ~newline~ But the tin soldier pretended not to hear  ~newline~ When the children came in the next morning  they placed the tin soldier in the window  ~newline~ Now  whether it was the goblin who did it  or the draught  is not known  but the window flew open  and out fell the tin soldier  heels over head  from the third  story  into the street beneath  ~newline~ When it was over  two boys happened to pass by  and one of them said   Look  there is a tin soldier  ~newline~ So they made a boat out of a newspaper  and placed the tin soldier in it  and sent him sailing down the gutter  while the two boys ran by the side of it  and clapped their hands  ~newline~ The paper boat rocked up and down  and turned itself round sometimes so quickly that the tin soldier trembled  yet he remained firm  his countenance did not change  he looked straight before him  and shouldered his musket  ~newline~ Suddenly the boat shot under a bridge which formed a part of a drain  and then it was as dark as the tin soldier s box  ~newline~ But the tin soldier remained silent and held his musket tighter than ever  ~newline~ The tin soldier could already see daylight shining where the arch ended  ~newline~ He was too close to it to stop  so the boat rushed on  and the poor tin soldier could only hold himself as stiffly as possible  without moving an eyelid  to show that he was not afraid  ~newline~ ever brave  Drifting onward to thy grave   ~newline~ A great deal darker than in the tunnel  and narrower too  but the tin soldier continued firm  and lay at full length shouldering his musket  ~newline~ After a while  a flash of lightning seemed to pass through him  and then the daylight approached  and a voice cried out   I declare here is the tin soldier   ~newline~ It touched the tin soldier so much to see her that he almost wept tin tears  but he kept them back  ~newline~ Presently one of the little boys took up the tin soldier  and threw him into the stove  ~newline~ The flames lighted up the tin soldier  as he stood  the heat was very terrible  but whether it proceeded from the real fire or from the fire of love he could not tell  ~newline~ He felt himself melting away  but he still remained firm with his gun on his shoulder  ~newline~ Suddenly the door of the room flew open and the draught of air caught up the little dancer  she fluttered like a sylph right into the stove by the side of the tin soldier  and was instantly in flames and was gone  ~newline~ The tin soldier melted down into a lump  and the next morning  when the maid servant took the ashes out of the stove  she found him in the shape of a little tin heart  ~newline~ But of the little dancer nothing remained but the tinsel rose  which was burnt black as a cinder

title: The Brave Tin Soldier
sentence: The Brave Tin Soldier by Hans Christian Andersen THERE were once five and twenty tin soldiers  who were all brothers  for they had been made out of the same old tin spoon  ~newline~ The first thing in the world they ever heard were the words   Tin soldiers   ~newline~ The soldiers were all exactly alike  excepting one  who had only one leg  he had been left to the last  and then there was not enough of the melted tin to finish him  so they made him to stand firmly on one leg  and this caused him to be very remarkable  ~newline~ The table on which the tin soldiers stood  was covered with other playthings  but the most attractive to the eye was a pretty little paper castle  ~newline~ The little lady was a dancer  and she stretched out both her arms  and raised one of her legs so high  that the tin soldier could not see it at all  and he thought that she  like himself  had only one leg  ~newline~ When evening came  the other tin soldiers were all placed in the box  and the people of the house went to bed  ~newline~ The tin soldiers rattled in their box  they wanted to get out and join the amusements  but they could not open the lid  ~newline~ Only the tin soldier and the dancer remained in their places  ~newline~  Tin soldier   said the goblin   don t wish for what does not belong to you  ~newline~ But the tin soldier pretended not to hear  ~newline~ When the children came in the next morning  they placed the tin soldier in the window  ~newline~ Now  whether it was the goblin who did it  or the draught  is not known  but the window flew open  and out fell the tin soldier  heels over head  from the third  story  into the street beneath  ~newline~ When it was over  two boys happened to pass by  and one of them said   Look  there is a tin soldier  ~newline~ So they made a boat out of a newspaper  and placed the tin soldier in it  and sent him sailing down the gutter  while the two boys ran by the side of it  and clapped their hands  ~newline~ The paper boat rocked up and down  and turned itself round sometimes so quickly that the tin soldier trembled  yet he remained firm  his countenance did not change  he looked straight before him  and shouldered his musket  ~newline~ Suddenly the boat shot under a bridge which formed a part of a drain  and then it was as dark as the tin soldier s box  ~newline~ But the tin soldier remained silent and held his musket tighter than ever  ~newline~ The tin soldier could already see daylight shining where the arch ended  ~newline~ He was too close to it to stop  so the boat rushed on  and the poor tin soldier could only hold himself as stiffly as possible  without moving an eyelid  to show that he was not afraid  ~newline~ He now stood up to his neck in water  while deeper and deeper sank the boat  and the paper became soft and loose with the wet  till at last the water closed over the soldier s head  ~newline~   Then the paper boat fell to pieces  and the soldier sank into the water and immediately afterwards was swallowed up by a great fish  ~newline~ A great deal darker than in the tunnel  and narrower too  but the tin soldier continued firm  and lay at full length shouldering his musket  ~newline~ After a while  a flash of lightning seemed to pass through him  and then the daylight approached  and a voice cried out   I declare here is the tin soldier   ~newline~ She picked up the soldier and held him by the  waist between her finger and thumb  and carried him into the room  ~newline~ They were all anxious to see this wonderful soldier who had travelled about inside a fish  but he was not at all proud  ~newline~ It touched the tin soldier so much to see her that he almost wept tin tears  but he kept them back  ~newline~ Presently one of the little boys took up the tin soldier  and threw him into the stove  ~newline~ The flames lighted up the tin soldier  as he stood  the heat was very terrible  but whether it proceeded from the real fire or from the fire of love he could not tell  ~newline~ Suddenly the door of the room flew open and the draught of air caught up the little dancer  she fluttered like a sylph right into the stove by the side of the tin soldier  and was instantly in flames and was gone  ~newline~ The tin soldier melted down into a lump  and the next morning  when the maid servant took the ashes out of the stove  she found him in the shape of a little tin heart

title: The Brave Tin Soldier
sentence: uttered by a little boy  who clapped his hands with delight when the lid of the box  in which they lay  was taken off  ~newline~ The table on which the tin soldiers stood  was covered with other playthings  but the most attractive to the eye was a pretty little paper castle  ~newline~ In front of the castle a number of little trees surrounded a piece of looking glass  which was intended to represent a transparent lake  ~newline~ All this was very pretty  but the prettiest of all was a tiny little lady  who stood at the open door of the castle  she  also  was made of paper  and she wore a dress of clear muslin  with a narrow blue ribbon over her shoulders just like a scarf  ~newline~ The little lady was a dancer  and she stretched out both her arms  and raised one of her legs so high  that the tin soldier could not see it at all  and he thought that she  like himself  had only one leg  ~newline~ Then he laid himself at full length on the table behind a snuff box that stood upon it  so that he could peep at the little delicate lady  who continued to stand on one leg without losing her balance  ~newline~ The clock struck twelve  and  with a bounce  up sprang the lid of the snuff box  but  instead of snuff  there jumped up a little black goblin  for the snuff box was a toy puzzle  ~newline~ The servant maid and the little boy went down stairs directly to look for him  but he was nowhere to be seen  although once they nearly trod upon him  ~newline~ Ah  well  if the little lady were only here with me in the boat  I should not care for any darkness   ~newline~ He thought of the elegant little dancer whom he should never see again  and the words of the song sounded in his ears    Farewell  warrior  ~newline~ They placed him on the table  and  how many curious things do happen in the world   there he was in the very same room from the window of which he had fallen  there were the same children  the same playthings  standing on the table  and the pretty castle with the elegant little dancer at the door  she still balanced herself on one leg  and held up the other  so she was as firm as himself  ~newline~ Presently one of the little boys took up the tin soldier  and threw him into the stove  ~newline~ He looked at the little lady  and she looked at him  ~newline~ Suddenly the door of the room flew open and the draught of air caught up the little dancer  she fluttered like a sylph right into the stove by the side of the tin soldier  and was instantly in flames and was gone  ~newline~ The tin soldier melted down into a lump  and the next morning  when the maid servant took the ashes out of the stove  she found him in the shape of a little tin heart  ~newline~ But of the little dancer nothing remained but the tinsel rose  which was burnt black as a cinder

title: The Brave Tin Soldier

sentence: The table on which the tin soldiers stood  was covered with other playthings  but the most attractive to the eye was a pretty little paper castle  ~newline~ All this was very pretty  but the prettiest of all was a tiny little lady  who stood at the open door of the castle  she  also  was made of paper  and she wore a dress of clear muslin  with a narrow blue ribbon over her shoulders just like a scarf  ~newline~ So they made a boat out of a newspaper  and placed the tin soldier in it  and sent him sailing down the gutter  while the two boys ran by the side of it  and clapped their hands  ~newline~ The paper boat rocked up and down  and turned itself round sometimes so quickly that the tin soldier trembled  yet he remained firm  his countenance did not change  he looked straight before him  and shouldered his musket  ~newline~ He now stood up to his neck in water  while deeper and deeper sank the boat  and the paper became soft and loose with the wet  till at last the water closed over the soldier s head  ~newline~   Then the paper boat fell to pieces  and the soldier sank into the water and immediately afterwards was swallowed up by a great fish

title: The Brave Tin Soldier
sentence: They shouldered arms and looked straight before them  and wore a splendid uniform  red and blue  ~newline~ The paper boat rocked up and down  and turned itself round sometimes so quickly that the tin soldier trembled  yet he remained firm  his countenance did not change  he looked straight before him  and shouldered his musket  ~newline~ He only looked at her and they both remained silent  ~newline~ He looked at the little lady  and she looked at him

title: The Brave Tin Soldier
sentence: The soldiers were all exactly alike  excepting one  who had only one leg  he had been left to the last  and then there was not enough of the melted tin to finish him  so they made him to stand firmly on one leg  and this caused him to be very remarkable  ~newline~ She stood on tiptoe  with her legs stretched out  as firmly as he did on his one leg  ~newline~ The paper boat rocked up and down  and turned itself round sometimes so quickly that the tin soldier trembled  yet he remained firm  his countenance did not change  he looked straight before him  and shouldered his musket  ~newline~ A great deal darker than in the tunnel  and narrower too  but the tin soldier continued firm  and lay at full length shouldering his musket  ~newline~ They placed him on the table  and  how many curious things do happen in the world   there he was in the very same room from the window of which he had fallen  there were the same children  the same playthings  standing on the table  and the pretty castle with the elegant little dancer at the door  she still balanced herself on one leg  and held up the other  so she was as firm as himself  ~newline~ He felt himself melting away  but he still remained firm with his gun on his shoulder

title: The Brave Tin Soldier
sentence: Now  whether it was the goblin who did it  or the draught  is not known  but the window flew open  and out fell the tin soldier  heels over head  from the third  story  into the street beneath  ~newline~ Presently it began to rain  and the drops fell faster and faster  till there was a heavy shower  ~newline~ At the end of the tunnel  the drain fell into a large canal over a steep place  which made it as dangerous for him as a waterfall would be to us  ~newline~   Then the paper boat fell to pieces  and the soldier sank into the water and immediately afterwards was swallowed up by a great fish

title: The Brave Tin Soldier
sentence: The clock struck twelve  and  with a bounce  up sprang the lid of the snuff box  but  instead of snuff  there jumped up a little black goblin  for the snuff box was a toy puzzle  ~newline~  This is the black goblin s fault  I am sure  ~newline~ He had no reason for doing so  therefore it must have been the fault of the black goblin who lived in the snuff box  ~newline~ But of the little dancer nothing remained but the tinsel rose  which was burnt black as a cinder

title: The Brave Tin Soldier

title: The Brave Tin Soldier
